Gluteal Region.questionText: The sciatic nerve exits the pelvis through:
Which muscle is the most superficial in the gluteal region:
The gluteus medius and minimus are mainly supplied by:
The superior gluteal nerve emerges from the pelvis above:

options: Attached to the posterior part of iliac crest.
Innervated by the inferior gluteal nerve.
Lies deep to the gluteus medius muscle.

Gluteal Region.questionText: The most powerful extensor of the hip joint is:
Medial rotation of the thigh is done the following muscle:
A significant weakness in thigh abduction involve which muscle:
In walking, hip bone of the suspended leg is raised by which of the following muscles acting on the supported side of the body:
Paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus will result in the:
options: Inability to adduct the thigh at the hip joint.
Sinking of pelvis on the normal side when same foot is raised.
Inability to laterally rotate the thigh at the hip joint.
Waddling gate in case of bilateral paralysis of the muscles.

Gluteal Region.questionText: Regarding action of the glutei muscles, one answer is correct:
options: Gluteus maximus is medial rotator of the thigh.
Gluteus medius is adductor of the hip joint.
Both glutei maximus and medius are extensors of the hip joint.
Both glutei medius and minimus are powerful abductor of hip joint.

Gluteal Region.questionText: One of the following muscles is lateral rotator of the thigh:
The quadratus femoris is inserted into, choose the correct answer:
The following structure deep lies to the gluteus maximus:
options: Straight head of rectus femoris muscle.

Gluteal Region.questionText: The structure which passes through greater sciatic foramen is:
Which structure passes through the lesser sciatic foramen:
The following structure pass through the lesser sciatic foramen:
The powerful extension of the thigh, required when one is standing from a sitting position, is a function of the:
Root value of sciatic nerve is:

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the fascia of the thigh, mark the correct statements:
options: The fascia lata of thigh is thickened medially to form iliotibial tract.
The saphenous opening is a gap in the fascia lata.
The saphenous opening is 6 cm below and lateral to pubic tubercle.
Two facial septa pass from fascia lata to the femur.

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the iliotibial tract:
options: It is attached between iliac crest and lateral condyle of the tibia.
It receives the insertion of gluteus medius and tensor fascia lata.
It belongs to the investing layer of the deep fascia of the thigh.
It is connected to linea aspera by the medial intermuscular septum.

Thigh.questionText: The iliotibial tract receives attachment of the following muscle:
The cribriform fascia is pierced by:
One of following structures pass deep to the inguinal ligament:
Which of the following muscles is a flexor of the thigh:
The sartorius muscle:
options: Flexes the knee joint and extends the hip joint.
Is one of the boundaries of the femoral triangle.
Arises from the anterior inferior iliac spine.

Thigh.questionText: The sartorius muscle is:
options: It is innervated by the obturator nerve.
It arises from the anterior superior iliac spine.
It inserts on the lateral surface of the tibia.
It forms the medial border of the femoral triangle.

Thigh.questionText: A crushing blow that breaks the anterior superior iliac spine would damage the origin of the:
The head of the quadriceps muscle which acts on the hip joint:
Muscle that extends leg include the following muscle:
Regarding quadriceps femoris muscle, choose the correct answer:
The articularis genu muscle, mark the correct statement:
options: Is the deep fibers of the vastus medialis muscle.
Is fixed to the upper border of the suprapatellar bursa.
Is supplied by the obturator nerve.
Arises from the upper half of the medial surface of the femur.

Thigh.questionText: One of the following muscles is supplied by the obturator nerve:
Femoral vessels enter popliteal fossa through hiatus in which muscle:
The boundaries of the femoral triangle is by the following:
options: Inguinal ligament, sartorius and adductor longus.
Inguinal ligament, sartorius and adductor brevis.
Inguinal ligament, sartorius and adductor magnus.

Thigh.questionText: The base of the femoral triangle is formed by the:
In floor of femoral triangle one of the following muscles is seen:
The floor of the femoral triangle is bounded medially by:
In the femoral triangle one of the following branches arise from the femoral artery:
The femoral sheath:
options: Its medial compartment is occupied by the femoral artery.
Its lateral compartment is occupied by the femoral nerve.
The intermediate compartment is occupied by the femoral vein.
The anterior wall is formed by fascia iliaca.

Thigh.questionText: Concerning the femoral sheath, choose the correct answer:
options: It encloses the proximal portions of the popliteal artery and vein.
Posteriorly it is formed by the fascia transversalis.
The femoral nerve is medial to the femoral sheath.
The inguinal ligament is anterior to the femoral sheath.

Thigh.questionText: Femoral canal contains:
The femoral ring is bounded medially by:
Following form the medial boundary of femoral ring:
The femoral ring is bounded anteriorly by:
A femoral hernia descends through the femoral canal, and the neck of the hernial sac lies:
options: Above and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Thigh.questionText: Concerning the femoral hernia, choose the correct answer:
options: It is more common in males than females.
It occurs in the medial compartment of the femoral sheath.
It is found above and medial to the pubic tubercle.
Its neck is medial to the base of the lacunar ligament.

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the femoral sheath and femoral hernia, the following statement is true:
options: Femoral sheath is a prolongation of facial lining from the abdominal walls, along the upper part of femoral vessels.
Femoral canal is the lateral compartment of the femoral sheath.
Femoral hernia is more common in men than in women.
Neck of the femoral hernia lies below and medial to the pubic tubercle.

Thigh.questionText: The roof of the adductor canal is formed by one of the followings:
One of the following structures is in the adductor canal:
The following structures pass through the subsartorial canal from upper to lower end is:
options: Posterior division of the obturator nerve.

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the adductor (subsartorial) canal, choose the correct answer:
options: Vastus lateralis muscle in its lateral aspect.
Nerve plexus embedded in its posterior wall.
Descending branch from femoral artery which takes part in the anastomosis around the knee.
Nerve to the vastus lateralis muscle.

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the adductor (subsartorial) canal and its contents, mark one correct statement:
options: Its anteromedial wall is formed by the vastus medialis.
Its lateral wall is formed by the vastus lateralis.
Its posterior wall is formed by the adductor longus and magnus.
The femoral artery has no branches in the canal.

Thigh.questionText: Contents of the adductor (subsartorial) canal include one of the following:
Regarding adductor canal, the following statement is correct:
options: It ends at the adductor hiatus.
Its posterior wall is formed by the adductor brevis muscle only.
Its lateral wall is formed by the vastus lateralis.

Thigh.questionText: The femoral nerve originates from which of the following roots:
One muscle is supplied by the femoral nerve in the abdomen:
Damage to the femoral nerve on the lateral wall of the pelvis would affect the function of the following muscle:
The femoral nerve:
options: Comes from the dorsal divisions of the L2, 3 & 4.
Ends four inches below the inguinal ligament.
Supply all muscles of floor of femoral triangle except the pectineus.
Passes to thigh through lateral compartment of the femoral sheath.

Thigh.questionText: Concerning the femoral nerve it:
options: Enters the thigh medial to the femoral sheath.
Supplies motor nerves to most of the muscles of the anterior and medial compartments of the thigh.
Lies medial to the femoral artery in the femoral triangle.
Has no motor branches below the knee.

Thigh.questionText: Which of the following nerves innervates at least one muscle that acts on both the hip and the knee joints:
Loss of extension of the knee would result from damage to the:
Paralysis of saphenous nerve results in the following deformity:
options: Loss of sensation on the lateral malleolus.
Loss of sensation on the medial malleolus.
Loss of sensation on localized area on the dorsum of the foot.

Thigh.questionText: Regarding the patellar tendon reflex (knee jerk), mark one correct statement:
options: It is the flexion of the knee joint on tapping the patellar tendon.
It is a test for second, third and fourth lumbar spinal nerves.
It is a test for the hamstrings muscles.
It is a test for the calf muscles.

Thigh.questionText: The obturator nerve:
options: Gives a cutaneous branch to the lower medial side of the thigh.

Thigh.questionText: The obturator nerve supplies the following muscle:
Regarding the obturator nerve, mark correct answer:
options: Is formed by ventral divisions of 2, 3 and 4 lumbar nerves.
Leaves the pelvis through femoral sheath.

Thigh.questionText: The obturator nerve; mark the most suitable answer:
options: Is formed of the ventral divisions of L2, 3 & 4 nerves.
Supplies all the adductor and flexor thigh muscles.
It passes through the adductor canal.

Thigh.questionText: The adductor canal contains all EXCEPT:
Which nerve supplies the quadriceps muscle:
The hamstring muscles are innervated by:
The adductor brevis is supplied by:
The saphenous vein drains into:
Which of the following is NOT a medial compartment muscle:
The iliopsoas muscle inserts on:
Regarding the hamstring muscles (Posterior compartment of thigh), mark correct statement:
options: All are supplied by common peroneal nerve.
Biceps femoris produces medial rotation of knee.
Upper half of semimembranosus is membranous.

Thigh.questionText: Extension of the hip joint is done by the following muscle:
Lateral intermuscular septum of the thigh separates which of the following muscles:
The sciatic nerve supplies one of the following muscles:
To avoid sciatic nerve injury, an intramuscular injection in the gluteal region is given in which of the following quadrants:
From the muscles forming the floor of femoral triangle:
Among contents of the adducter canal is:

Leg.questionText: The anterior compartment of the leg contains:
options: Tibialis anterior, extensor digitorum longus, extensor hallucis longus
Tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum, flexor hallucis

Leg.questionText: The structure contributes to the above and lateral boundary of the popliteal fossa:
options: Medial head of the gastrocnemius muscle.

Leg.questionText: The common peroneal nerve divides into:
The superficial peroneal nerve innervates:
The deep peroneal nerve innervates:
options: Tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus

Leg.questionText: The sural nerve is formed by:
The popliteal fossa is bounded by:
options: Hamstrings superomedially, biceps femoris superolaterally, gastrocnemius inferiorly
Vastus medialis medially, rectus femoris anteriorly

Leg.questionText: The deep calf muscles are supplied by:
Regarding popliteal fossa, the following is correct statement:
options: Upper part of floor of fossa is formed of popliteal surface of the tibia.
It contains the medial cutaneous nerve of the thigh.
Popliteal artery pulsations can be felt while the knee is extended.
Semitendinosus forms its superior medial boundary.

Leg.questionText: The following structure attaches to the calcaneus:
The superficial muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg insert on which of the following bones:
The superficial calf muscles; select the correct statement:
options: Enters the foot by passing deep to the flexor retinaculum.

Leg.questionText: Regarding the gastrocnemius muscle, mark the correct answer:
options: Its medial head is attached to the popliteal surface of the femur above its medial condyle, it is the smaller head.
Its lateral head is attached to the femur above the medial epicondyle.
It is a plantar flexor at the ankle joint.
It receives its nerve supply from the anterior tibial nerve.

Leg.questionText: The muscle which act as plantar flexors of the foot include:
Regarding muscles of posterior compartment of leg, select the correct:
options: They are all supplied by anterior tibial nerve.
They receive their blood supply by anterior tibial artery.
They produce plantar flexion of foot.

Leg.questionText: Concerning the flexor hallucis longus muscle, choose the correct answer:
options: Grooves the lower surface of the calcaneus.
An important factor in maintaining the transverse arch of the foot.
Lies superficial to the flexor retinaculum.
Is supplied by posterior tibial nerve.

Leg.questionText: Regarding tibialis posterior muscle, indicate the correct statement:
options: It arises from tibia, fibula and interosseous membrane.
Its tendon passes superficial to that of flexor digitorum longus.
It produces inversion of the foot by acting at the ankle joint.
It helps in suspending the lateral longitudinal arch of the foot.

Leg.questionText: Regarding the posterior compartment of the leg, the following statement is correct:
options: Posterior tibial nerve crosses the posterior tibial artery from lateral to medial.
Pulsation from the posterior tibial artery is felt behind the lateral malleolus.
Plantar is can be used as autograft.
The peroneal artery is the smallest of the branches of posterior tibial artery.

Leg.questionText: Nerve commonly injured in fractured neck of the fibula is the:
Effects of common peroneal nerve injury include one:
options: Foot drop and inversion of the foot.
Foot drop and eversion of the foot.
Dorsi flexion and eversion of the foot.
Dorsi flexion and inversion of the foot.

Leg.questionText: Damage to posterior tibial nerve would affect following muscle:
Following structure is located in anterior compartment of leg:
Which of the following muscles dorsiflexes foot at ankle joint:
The following muscle evert the foot:
As the deep peroneal nerve descends through the leg, it is joined by which of the following arteries:
One of the following muscles is supplied by the deep peroneal nerve:
The following muscle lies in the lateral compartment of the leg:
The muscles supplied by the superficial peroneal nerve; mark the correct answer:
options: Passes in front of the lateral malleolus.

Leg.questionText: Following muscle everts the foot:
Weak inversion of foot results from damage to which muscle:
Superficial peroneal nerve supplies one of following muscles:
Clinical finding of superficial peroneal nerve injury includes:
options: Loss of plantar flexion of the ankle.
Loss of sensations of the sole of the foot.
Paralysis of muscles of the lateral compartment of the leg.

Leg.questionText: Regarding attachment of muscles of lower limb, choose correct answer:
options: Gluteus maximus is inserted to the greater trochanter of femur.
The adductor longus is inserted to the linea aspera of femur.
The tibialis anterior arises from the medial surface of the tibia.
The peroneus longus is inserted to the base of 5th metatarsal bone.

Leg.questionText: Concerning nerves of the lower limb, which statement is true:
options: Sciatic nerve supplies gluteus maximus muscle.
Deep peroneal nerve supplies peroneal longus and brevis.

Leg.questionText: Bone which fracture in over doing the movement of eversion is:
options: The inferior margin of lower end of tibia.

Leg.questionText: For bone grafts in the leg and foot, the most suitable place is:
The popliteal fossa contains the following structure:

Foot.questionText: The medial longitudinal arch is mainly supported by:
The transverse arch of the foot is supported by:
The plantar fascia originates from:
The intrinsic muscles of the foot are supplied by:
The first layer of plantar muscles includes:
options: Abductor hallucis, flexor digitorum brevis, abductor digiti minimi

Foot.questionText: Pes planus is caused by:
options: Loss of medial arch due to ligament laxity or muscle weakness
Excessive arching of the medial arch

Foot.questionText: The ankle joint is formed between:
The subtalar joint allows:
Muscles of the first layer of the sole; choose the correct statement:
options: Abductor hallucis lies on the lateral side.
Flexor digitorum brevis lies on the medial side.
Flexor digitorum accessorius lies in this layer.
Abductor digiti minimi lies on the lateral side.

Foot.questionText: Third layer of the sole; choose the correct statement:
options: Flexor hallucis brevis lies on the lateral side.
Lumbrical muscles lie in this layer.
Flexor digiti minimi lies on the medial side.

Foot.questionText: Regarding the medial plantar nerve, select the correct answer:
options: It arises from the anterior tibial nerve deep to the flexor retinaculum.
It supplies flexor digitorum brevis muscle.
It supplies medial two plantar interossei muscles.

Foot.questionText: Regarding muscle actions in lower limb, the following is correct:
options: Quadriceps femoris flexes the knee joint.
Interossei abduct and adduct the toes from the middle of the second toe.
Muscles inserted in tendo calcaneus are dorsi flexors.
Gluteus maximus is a powerful flexor of hip joint.

Foot.questionText: Regarding lower limb bones, the following statement is correct:
options: Patella is the smallest sesamoid bone.
Posterior border of tibia is subcutaneous through its entire length.
Lower end of the shaft of femur possesses two condyles.
Middle of third toe is taken as the axis of abduction and adduction.

Foot.questionText: Eversion and inversion of the foot occur at; mark the suitable answer:
The movements of inversion and eversion take place at:
Inversion of the foot is done by; mark the correct answer:
options: Tibialis anterior and tibialis posterior muscles.

Foot.questionText: The cuboid bone; mark the most appropriate statement:
options: Gives attachment to the spring ligament.
Shares in the lateral longitudinal arch.

Foot.questionText: Regarding the spring ligament, choose the correct answer:
options: Gives attachment to the deltoid ligament.
Important for maintaining the transverse arch of the foot.

Foot.questionText: Sesamoid bones are found in the sole in the following layer:
Important factor in maintaining foot arches:
options: Lateral longitudinal arch is supported by tibialis posterior.
Abductor digiti minimi supports the medial longitudinal arch.
Tendon of peroneus longus supports the transverse arch.
Tendon of flexor hallucis longus supports the lateral longitudinal arch.

Foot.questionText: Regarding foot arches, the following is correct:
options: Head of talus is the keystone in the center of the lateral longitudinal arch.
Short and long plantar ligaments support the medial longitudinal arch.
Flat foot is produced by depression of the arches.
The cuboid is the center of the medial longitudinal arch.

Foot.questionText: Factors maintaining foot arches include:
options: Medial longitudinal arch is supported by long plantar ligament.
Lateral longitudinal arch is supported by tibialis posterior.
Tendon of tibialis anterior suspends the lateral longitudinal arch.
Tendon of peroneus longus acts as a tie beam for the transverse arch.

Foot.questionText: Lesion of the medial plantar nerve could cause:
options: Loss of cutaneous sensation to the adjacent sides of the plantar surface of the 1st and 2nd toes.
Paralysis of flexor digitorum accessorius muscle.

Joints.questionText: Unlocking of the knee joint to permit flexion is caused by the action of which muscle:
Which of the following is an intra-articular tendon:
The neck of the femur:
options: Makes an angle of about 160 degrees with the shaft.

Joints.questionText: Regarding the femur; indicate the correct answer:
options: Its head can be palpated medial to the pulsations of femoral artery.
Decrease in angle between its neck and shaft limits its abduction.
Subcapital fracture of its neck is common in old age.
Fracture of its lower third often interferes with blood flow to leg.

Joints.questionText: Regarding fracture of the neck of the femur, select the true statement:
options: Produces necrosis of the greater trochanter.
Is easy to heal in old age.
The limb rotates laterally after this fracture.

Joints.questionText: The strongest ligament of the hip joint is:
Trochanteric line gives attachment to; mark suitable answer:
Hyperextension of the hip joint is limited by:
options: Ligament of the head of the femur.

Joints.questionText: Regarding the hip joint, choose the correct answer:
options: It is a synovial joint of condyloid variety.
Its extension is performed by gluteus minimus muscle.
Its main flexor is the quadriceps femoris muscle.
The iliofemoral ligament limits its hyperextension.

Joints.questionText: Regarding the adductor tubercle of the femur, choose the correct answer:
options: Used as a point to draw the surface anatomy of the popliteal artery.
Gives attachment to the medial ligament of the knee joint.
Gives attachment to the adductor brevis muscle.
At the lower end of medial supracondylar line.

Joints.questionText: The lower epiphyseal plate of the femur:
options: Is the rapidly growing end of the femur.
Is closed earlier than the upper epiphyseal plate.
Passes through the linea aspera of the femur.
The nutrient foramen is directed to it.

Joints.questionText: Regarding the knee joint:
options: The tendon of popliteus muscle is intracapsular, intrasynovial.
The popliteus muscle locks the knee joint at the beginning of flexion.
Lateral meniscus is more liable to injury than the medial meniscus.
Locking of the joint occurs at the end of extension.

Joints.questionText: Regarding the knee joint, the following is true:
options: Its lateral meniscus is damaged more frequently than the medial.
Its lateral meniscus is attached to the lateral collateral ligament.
Rupture of its anterior cruciate ligament results in excessive backward movement of tibia on femur.
Stability of joint depends largely on tone of quadriceps femoris muscle.

Joints.questionText: The following is inside the knee joint:
Tibial collateral ligament of the knee extends from medial epicondyle of femur to:
Regarding ligaments of knee joint, mark the correct statement:
options: The ligamentum patellae replaces capsule in its anterior and lower part.
Lateral collateral ligament is attached to lateral meniscus.
Medial collateral ligament is not attached to the medial meniscus.
In rupture of anterior cruciate ligament, there is excessive backward movement of tibia on femur.

Joints.questionText: In a locked knee which of following ligaments becomes taut:
Common football injury in the knee joint is rupture of:
Regarding the patella, choose the correct answer:
options: It gives attachment to the quadriceps tendon to its upper part and ligamentum patellae to the lower part.
Its displacement in the medial direction is prevented by the large medial condyle of the femur.
It is separated from the skin by a fascia liable to swelling.
It receives lower horizontal fibers of the adductor longus forming patellar retinaculum.

Joints.questionText: The bone that fractures in over-eversion is the:
options: Inferior margin of lower end of tibia.

Joints.questionText: The primary weight support at the ankle joint is provided by:
Which statement is true regarding the ankle joint:
options: It is strengthened laterally by the deltoid ligament.
It is formed by the articulation of the talus and the distal ends of the tibia and fibula.
It is most stable in the fully plantar-flexed position.

Joints.questionText: Movements of flexion and extension of the foot occur in the following joint:
The deltoid ligament; mark the correct answer:
options: Lies on the lateral aspect of the ankle joint.
Attached inferiorly to the spring ligament.

Joints.questionText: Which ligament limits extension of the hip joint:
In injuries of the knee, the medial meniscus is frequently torn because it is firmly attached to:
The thickest and strongest ligament of the hip joint is the:

Attached to the head of femur is:

Tibia and Fibula.questionText: All the following regarding tibia are true Except:
options: It is the lateral and stronger bone of the leg
It is the longest bone excepting the femur
It gives attachment to popliteus and semimembranosus

Tibia and Fibula.questionText: As regards tibial tuberosity, all are true Except:
options: Lies at upper end of anterior border of tibia
Has upper smooth & lower rough areas
Ligamentum patellae attaches to its rough part

Tibia and Fibula.questionText: The following structures pass behind the medial malleolus Except:
Regarding fibula, all are true Except.:
options: It is the lateral bone of the leg
It is not directly involved in weight transmission
styloid process projects from its lower end
Its lateral aspect of lateral malleolus is subcutaneous

options: It develops in the tendon of biceps femoris
At its apex, ligameutum patellae is attached

Patella.questionText: The patella is located in the tendon of which of the following muscles?:

Foot Bones.questionText: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tarsal bones?:
options: Cuboid lies medially in the foot
Calcaneus is the smallest tarsal bone
Navicular lies just in front of the cuneiforms

options: The head of talus is the 'keystone' in the center of the medial longitudinal arch
Flat foot is produced by the depression of the arches
The cuboid is the 'keystone' in the center of the lateral longitudinal arch
In young child the foot appears to be flat

Foot Bones.questionText: Following are important factors in maintaining arches of the foot, Except:
options: Medial longitudinal arch is supported by abductor hallucis
Lateral longitudinal arch is supported by tibialis posterior
